link_type.title: The type of data linking task -  `link_and_dedupe` or `link_only`.  Required.
link_type.description: - When `link_and_dedupe`, `splink` finds links within and between input datasets.  If  single dataset is provided, it will be deduped. - When `link_only`,  `splink` finds links between datasets, but does not attempt to deduplicate the datasets (it does not try and find links within each input dataset.)

proportion_of_matches.title: The proportion of record comparisons thought to be matches
proportion_of_matches.description: This provides the initial value (prior) from which the EM algorithm will start iterating

em_convergence.title: Convergence tolerance for the EM algorithm
em_convergence.description: The algorithm will stop converging when the maximum of the change in model parameters between iterations is below this value

max_iterations.title: The maximum number of iterations to run even if convergence has not been reached
max_iterations.description: Set this value to zero if you do not want to use the EM algorithm and just want to score matches from values you have manually specified in the `m_probabilities` and `u_probabilities` arrays

unique_id_column_name.title: The name of the column in the input dataset representing a unique id
unique_id_column_name.description: For linking tasks, ids must be unique to each dataset being linked, and do not need to be globally unique across these two datasets

source_dataset_column_name.title: The name of the column in the input dataset representing the source dataset
source_dataset_column_name.description: Where we are linking datasets, we can't guarantee that the unique id column is globally unique across datasets, so we combine it with a source_dataset column

retain_matching_columns.title: If set to true, each column in the `comparison_columns` array will be retained in output datasets
retain_matching_columns.description: This is helpful so that the user can inspect matches, but once the comparison vector (gamma) columns are computed, this information is not actually needed by the algorithm.  The algorithm will run faster and use less resources if this is set to false.

retain_intermediate_calculation_columns.title: Retain intermediate calculation columns, such as the individual m and u probabilities associated with each column in `comparison_columns`
retain_intermediate_calculation_columns.description: The algorithm will run faster and use less resources if this is set to false.

comparison_columns.title: A list of columns to use for probabalistic matching
comparison_columns.description: Comparisons between the values in these columns will be used to determine match scores

items.title: A comparison of input column(s) that is used for probabalistic matching

col_name.title: The name of the column in the input dataset. Required, unless a `custom_name` is used instead

num_levels.title: The number of different similarity categories (gradations of similarity) that will be computed for this column.
num_levels.description: See [here](https://imai.fas.harvard.edu/research/files/linkage.pdf), page 355 equation (1). A greater value for `num_levels` means the algorithm can be more granular about how string similarity is treated - e.g. with three levels, it enables it to make a distinction between strings which are an almost-exact match, strings which are quite similar, and strings which don't match at all.  However, more levels results in longer compute times and can sometimes affect convergence. By default, for a string variable, two levels would implies level 0: no match, level 1: almost exact match.  Three levels imples level 0: no match, level 1: strings are similar but not exactly the same, level 2: strings are almost exactly the same.  This column determines which pre-configured SQL CASE expression is used to generate values in the comparison vector.

data_type.title: The data type of the column.  This is used to choose how similarity is assessed this column. This is ignored if you explicitly provide a case_expression.
data_type.description:
- If `string` is specified, `splink` will use the Jaro Winkler string comparison functions.
- If `numeric` is specified, then similarity will be assessed based on the absolute percentage difference between the two values.

custom_name.title: Custom name to identify this comparison in charts and calculations.  Required if `col_name` is not specified.
custom_name.description: If supplying a custom case expression that is not specific to a single input column, you must provide

custom_columns_used.title: A list of the columns required by the custom case expression used for this custom column. Required if custom_name is specified
custom_columns_used.description: When using a custom comparison, this is required so splink knows what columns to retain

case_expression.title: A SELECT CASE expression that compares the values of the input column and returns integer values corresponding to num_levels. Nulls should be explicitly dealt with in the case expression, and should be assigned a value of -1, see examples.
case_expression.description: This is an override which allows the user to customise how similarity is computed.  If given, this overrides the default mechanism of comparing columns and ignores data_type
examples:
CASE 
WHEN first_name_l is null or first_name_r is null then -1 
WHENfirst_name_l = first_name_r THEN 1 ELSE 0 END

CASE 
WHEN first_name_l is null or first_name_r is null then -1 
WHEN jaro_winkler_sim(first_name_l, first_name_r) < 0.94 THEN 2 
 WHEN jaro_winkler_sim(first_name_l, first_name_r) < 0.8 THEN 1 
  ELSE 0 END

m_probabilities.title: A array of the 'starting' m probabilities for this column (the priors, which are fed into the EM algorithm). These are the probabilities of observing each similarity level amongst matches.  There will be `num_level` values in this array.  See [here](http://imai.fas.harvard.edu/research/files/linkage.pdf) equation (2) of page 355, for further details - these probabilities correspond to the parameters of the discrete distribution designated by pi
m_probabilities.description: The first probability given corresponds to level 0: least similar.  It refers to the probability of observing level 0 in the comparison vector if the record really is a match.  The second probability corresponds to level 1, up to level n, most similar.

fix_m_probabilities.title: If true, prevent the m probabilities for this column being updated during iterations of the EM algorithm.
fix_m_probabilities.description: Warning: Setting this to true may prevent convergence

u_probabilities.title: A array of the 'starting' u probabilities for this column (the priors, which are fed into the EM algorithm). These are the probabilities of observing each similarity level amongst non-matches.  There will be `num_level` values in this array.  See [here](http://imai.fas.harvard.edu/research/files/linkage.pdf) equation (2) of page 355, for further details - these probabilities correspond to the parameters of the discrete distribution designated by pi
u_probabilities.description: The first probability given corresponds to level 0: least similar.  It refers to the probability of observing level 0 in the comparison vector if the record 'in reality' is not a match.  The second probability corresponds to level 1, up to level n, most similar.

fix_u_probabilities.title: If true, prevent the u probabilities for this column being updated during iterations of the EM algorithm.
fix_u_probabilities.description: Warning: Setting this to true may prevent convergence

term_frequency_adjustments.title: Whether ex post term frequency adjustments should be made to match scores for this column
term_frequency_adjustments.description: For some columns such as first name, the value of first name is important due to the distribution of values being non-uniform.  For instance, a match on 'linacre' contains more information than a match on 'smith. If this is set to true, a term frequency adjustment is made to account for these difference.  For details of how this works, see [here](https://static.cambridge.org/content/id/urn:cambridge.org:id:article:S0003055418000783/resource/name/S0003055418000783sup001.pdf) page 7

gamma_index.title: The comparison vector index.  This is an implementation detail and users should not set this manually.
gamma_index.description: Gamma values in the comparison vector will be put in columns called gamma_0, gamma_1 etc.  This is the gamma index corresponding to this column

blocking_rules.title: A list of one or more blocking rules to apply. A cartesian join is applied if `blocking_rules` is empty or not supplied.
blocking_rules.description: Each rule is a SQL expression representing the blocking rule, which will be used to create a join.  The left table is aliased with `l` and the right table is aliased with `r`. For example, if you want to block on a `first_name` column, the blocking rule would be `l.first_name = r.first_name`.  Note that splink deduplicates the comparisons generated by the blocking rules. If empty or not supplied, all comparisons between the input dataset(s) will be generated and blocking will not be used. For large input datasets, this will generally be computationally intractable because it will generate comparisons equal to the number of rows squared.

items.title: Each item in the array is a SQL expression represing a left join ON condition

additional_columns_to_retain.title: A list of columns not being used in the probabalistic matching comparisons that you want to include in your results.
additional_columns_to_retain.description: A common example is if the user has labelled data (training data) and wishes to retain the labels in the outputs

items.title: Individual strings representing other columns to retain
